page.title: 01Barton Abbey Estate
page.content: The first lord of the manor was Bishop Odo of Bayeux, and the present house was built c.1524, although it was not named 'Abbey' until 1860. An attic room, 92 ft long, was painted with frescoes and fitted as a Roman Catholic chapel in the sixteenth century. In the nineteenth century the house had a large estate of 2,500 acres, consisting of 5 farms, but in the 1920s the estate was split up. Now Barton Abbey estate has 300 acres of parkland and 1,710 acres of farmland, including Home Farm, Church Farm, Leys Farm and Whistlow. Most of the farmland is used for cereal growing, and the parkland for grazing sheep. The grounds of Barton Abbey have always been used for fetes and flower shows, and more recently for gymkhanas - the 15th was held there in 1985.
